displayed_text: Patient: Huh? Doctor: Last time, what happened? Did they give you the medicine? Patient: No, I, I, I just, the last one you gave me is the one that I lost. But I picked up the one that you gave me before then. Doctor: Before? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So, you picked it up on August thirtieth? Patient: The, no, the, I think Doctor: The last medication? Patient: No, I think the fifth. I think the fifth. Doctor: The fifth of September. Patient: Yeah, the fifth. Doctor: Okay. So, I’m going to then, uh, give you one with this date, with the end of September date. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: -but I can find out if somebody… Family Member: Was scheduled the same day or something. Doctor: But I assume that’s not the case, but I’ll just double check. Patient: Alright. Family Member: Okay. (sighs) Doctor: No. It’ll be back by tomorrow. Family Member: Okay. And that won’t change the course of what you recommend anyway? Doctor: It’s either gonna be zero or like point one or two so um. Family Member: What if it’s not though? What if it hasn’t gone down that much? Does that lead us to believe…? Doctor: It’s still not gonna change what we’re gonna do. Patient: Right.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: I would say I wouldn’t want to look back and not do everything I could have done. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: We might not cure you, but I think psychologically, you know I’ve done everything I can. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: But that you know, people feel differently. The only thing I say is you know to people is you really, really do have to do the radiation and the hormones. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: And that’s, and the data is clear. Everything else we’re doing you have to do is you know unmeasurable. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Because if you do the radiation and hormones you have a fifty/fifty shot at being cured. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So if the cancer never comes back you don’t know if what we did helped or not. Right, I admit that.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - because up until this point we’ve been talking about you have an invisible cancer. Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: We know that it has recurred; we simply cannot see it or spot it or target that. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Um the reality is that we have tried that in the past and we still do that on occasion in certain patients. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: All the lymph nodes are connected to each other by so-called lymphatic system - Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and so the the the concern about targeting one particular lymph node or maybe two lymph nodes or three lymph nodes is is that um you might only be affecting you know ten percent, fifteen percent, thirty percent of the cancer cells in your body.

Patient: You know I got that motorcycle. Doctor: I know. Family Member: Please stop. Didn’t I tell you to stay off that motorcycle? Patient: You didn’t tell me to stay off my motorcycle. Family Member: From the last time we were here, I’ve told him to stop being on that motorcycle. Doctor: Well we worry about you being on that motorcycle. You know that. I know it’s what you love. You love being on that motorcycle but I worry about the way your back is and all this stuff. I just worry about it. Patient: Okay. Okay so here’s the deal. Doctor: Okay. Patient: First of all, I’m not on a motorcycle, motorcycle, I’m on a starship. I got two wheels up front, I got one wheel in the back. I got air shocks, Family Member: Excuse me. Patient: I got a custom built suit that I had custom built Doctor: Uh huh. Okay. Patient: for me with cush you see what I’m saying. I got all the controls in everything I do.

Family Member: Now he also if he says I’m through with this, I don’t want it no more. Doctor: Then we stop. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Absolutely. Healthcare Professional: This is totally voluntary. You don’t have to do the study medication. I mean the study, like she said, this medication he can get off study. Doctor: Right. Healthcare Professional: And if he feels like he’s having side effects or just doesn’t want to do it anymore or participate, just let me know. Doctor: Same thing. I would manage the side effects whether you’re on the study or not. Family Member: Right. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Whether you’re on the study or not, you have a problem at one a.m. on a Saturday, you still page me.

Patient: Well, one thing, I said the wrong side. It’s not the right side. It’s the left side. Doctor: Uh-huh. Patient: But I’m starting to think I . I wouldn’t even do that. Doctor: So it got a little worse from when you saw me but actually it hasn’t gotten worse in the last week or so? Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Okay. Okay. So there’s only one medicine on here that I’m looking at. Huh, do you take acyclovir? Did they put you on that? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Huh, so are you finished with that? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. And then so you’re still taking the abiraterone four pills a day? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Huh, the acyclovir is the one that they’ve asked you to take for ten days, probably for this? Huh, the Dulcolax to help for constipation? The Natural Tears now for your eye? The iron pill one, huh, three times a day? Patient: Yep. Well.

Family Member: I’m hoping. I’m looking for a little light of sunshine. Okay. And then the extra nodule that doesn’t say what that was. It just says it had extended out of one, the one positive node. Right? Doctor: So that’s not a ray of sunshine. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So node looks like that, actually they’re smaller. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And they can get cancer in them and then cancer can grow out of that a little bit. That’s extra nodule extension. Family Member: Um hum and you don’t know what that’s touching other nodes or other areas of the body? Doctor: No it’s just a sign, it’s like a sign like or more aggressiveness. We call it a prognostic factor. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It doesn’t mean that it’s touching something else. Family Member: And do they normally, do you normally just get a sampling of lymph nodes or is there a certain number you see or amount? Doctor: There’s a region that we remove lymph nodes. Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: Right, the part two – part one of this phase one series. Doctor: Oh I see okay got it. So it’s the dose expansion. Yeah so far there are some people who have benefited and been on it for quite a while. So there is some preliminary evidence of his Family Member: Just not a lot of data. Doctor: Yeah but it’s not – the numbers are not that big to really say statistics. Family Member: Right. Doctor: I would say probably two or three people out of the ten, but some of them haven’t even had their first scan yet. So it’s a work in progress. Family Member: Sure. Uh is there any data on uh chemotherapy? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Chemotherapy is standard and approved. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So the chances of that helping the – the other part is a lot of these new treatments like the Xofigo for instance, the radiation, it doesn’t make the PSA go down. So its the PSA effect is frequently treatment dependent. Okay so chemotherapy or XTANDI for that matter we know it makes the PSA go down if it’s working. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: But not so for Xofigo and for this new medication honestly we don’t know enough- Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Alright. Doctor: Alright so I don’t think anything else except we’ll wait and see. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we’ll be in touch once we know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. Healthcare Professional: Do we have to take for that too? Patient: So you want me to have her set up for one week from today? Doctor: Yeah, next week. Patient: Okay, alrighty. Doctor: Yep, yep and if I don’t need you to come we’ll call you and let you know… Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Same. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But we appreciate… Healthcare Professional: But you can always call me too… (laughs) Doctor: Yeah. (Laughter) Family Member: I’ll get your time too. Doctor: I’ll leave you guys too. I just wanted to come in and join the party for a minute. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Great. Doctor: But I know there’s more to be discussed. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And add either chemo or add a hormone drug to it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that would be what we would talk about. We do have trials where we're trying to even build on that. Okay, so hormones plus chemo plus immune therapy or hormones plus hormone therapy plus immune system drugs. Patient: Right. Doctor: So how, you know, one is sort of yet such small disease that we're going to try to manage it without using a traditional method, versus we think you've got so much disease that we're going to throw the kitchen sink at you, right? Wow. Okay. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I mean, that is why. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The Aximun scan may help and may also confuse thing. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But I'll hear from you anything that says we got to rush to therapy make a decision right now that I just need to figure out. We are adding Aximun scans to our scanning facility but we don't do them now. Patient: Right.

Patient: Um my sister and my great-niece. Doctor: Sister and great-niece. A-and i-i-is your great-niece working or is she at home? Is she- Patient: She-she work. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Mhm. She probably gon’ be there Doctor: Okay. Well um, you might be right that the PSA level could be rising. We’ll find out by uh later this afternoon or tomorrow morning at the latest. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But, I I did want to speak to you about um a research study that we’re doing that I think would be a good fit for you and I wanted to give you some details about that. Patient: Mm-kay. Doctor: And then give you some time to uh look at some written information that I’ll give you to take home. And you can look at that with your sister and your great-niece and the three of you can decide together whether you think this might be good idea for you. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And um I just wanted to um write some notes down. And then after I write these notes, I’m going to give you some detailed information about the the clinical trials. So, if if you are not at J_____ H_____. If you were just seeing a medical oncologist without- private practice or community um then the next step for someone like you, where the cancer might be growing or progressing despite the Abiraterone-

Patient: Right. Doctor: that’s just too time consuming especially based on where you guys live and so on. Um but, in reviewing your scans it looks like it’s just all in your bones and not thank goodness in the organs or anywhere else. So, there is a liquid radiation that’s available for patients who have, Healthcare Professional: No its okay, I decided to come on in here. Doctor: We were just talking about radium um which is that liquid radiation that only patients who have stuff in their bones not liver or anywhere else would kind of be the right patient to get that medication and that’s like a one-minute injection that the radiation oncology doctors did once a month Patient: Okay. Doctor: and they do that six months so once a month for six months and that’s been shown to help people live longer and that’s actually FDA approved. So, one could run that through the insurance, you know get treated, and be on your way. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The good thing about that in addition to the survival is you have pain relief with that. So, actually if you didn’t have any pain, I couldn’t get that cleared through insurance because they only want people who have discomfort and pain. I’m not saying you have to be writhing on the floor Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: but you have to sort of say oh, yeah, I get pain so, you know, I know I have cancer. Um, but you’re actually a good candidate for that. You’re otherwise all your blood counts and everything is also good because if you were already coming in here with low white cells or low red cells you wouldn’t be great but you don’t have that problem. So, Patient: Okay. Doctor: maybe the next step should be this medicine called Xofigo which, you know, we can have a side effects sheet given to you. We have to run it through insurance. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s folks who have like not so much hair at this age who just easily lose it. You have a lot of hair. Patient: Yes. When I was on the uh Cometriq. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: It started a little thinning but it was turning white. Doctor: Yeah. Um hum. Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Patient: And then we adjusted the dose and it started coming. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: So. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: I had to straighten this way.
